Package com.atakmap.map.opengl

Interface GLMapRenderable

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    GLLayer, GLLayer2, GLLayer3, GLMapLayer3, GLResolvableMapRenderable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ContourLinesOverlay.GLOverlay, GLAbstractDataStoreRasterLayer2, GLAbstractDataStoreRasterLayer3, GLAbstractLayer, GLAbstractLayer2, GLAsynchronousLayer, GLAsynchronousLayer2, GLAsynchronousMapRenderable, GLAttachmentBillboardLayer, GLBaseMap, GLBatchGeometry, GLBatchGeometryCollection, GLBatchGeometryFeatureDataStoreRenderer, GLBatchGeometryRenderer, GLBatchLineString, GLBatchMultiLineString, GLBatchMultiPoint, GLBatchMultiPolygon, GLBatchPoint, GLBatchPolygon, GLCrosshairLayer, GLCustomGrid, GLDatasetRasterLayer2, GLDatasetRasterLayer3, GLDt2OutlineOverlay, GLGridLinesOverlay, GLHeatMap, GLLatLngZoneOverlay, GLMagnifierLayer, GLMapItemsDatabaseRenderer, GLMapTargetBubble, GLMobileImageryRasterLayer2, GLMobileImageryRasterLayer3, GLModelLayer, GLMosaicMapLayer, GLMosaicMapLayer2, GLMultiLayer, GLNativeImageryRasterLayer2, GLOffscreenIndicators, GLProxyLayer, GLQuadTileNode2, GLQuadTileNode4, GLRootMapGroupLayer, GLRubberModelLayer, GLTiledMapLayer2, GLTileMatrixLayer, GLTilePatch2, GLVectorTiles, GLVehicleModelLayer, GLVideoOverlayLayer, GLViewShed2, GLWidgetsLayer, GLWidgetsLayer, GLZonesOverlay
    public interface GLMapRenderable
    The base interface for renderable content in the map. The general pattern followed in the map engine is that the renderable is a content observer and not a content owner. This means that the renderable will retain a reference to some subject and render the content for that subject. The renderable will not assume ownership of the subject or any handles to the subject's content that the subject may have. Owner activities would include explicitly disposing of the subject or of resources previously allocated by the subject.

    Lifecycle

    The lifecycle of the renderer will consist of a single instantiation followed by zero or more draw/release cycles. The draw/release cycle will consist of one or more invocations of draw(GLMapView) followed by a single invocation of release(). There is no guarantee that release() will be invoked prior to finalization without a previous invocation of draw(GLMapView).

    Instantiation

    The renderable may be instantiated on any thread. Instantiation should be a lightweight and high-performance operation. The renderable should assign the reference to its subject but otherwise remain in an uninitialized state.

    Draw

    The renderable should perform initialization when its draw(GLMapView) method is invoked when it is in the uninitialized state. In the event that initialization will not be completed in frame-rate time (e.g. the time it would normally take to render one frame), it should be offloaded to a background thread. The renderable should generally perform callback registration on its subject during initialization. The renderable will be considered in the initializing state until initialization is complete and it moves into the initialized state or the release() method has been invoked. The general pattern followed is that the renderable will return immediately from its draw(GLMapView) method while in the initializing state.

    Once in the initialized state, the renderable should render the appropriate content during each invocation of the draw(GLMapView) method. In the event that construction of the scene for the current GLMapView state cannot be completed within frame-rate time, scene construction should be offloaded to a background thread.

    Release

    The renderable will release all resources allocated during initialization when its release() method is invoked. The renderable will be moved into the uninitialized state prior to the method returning. Generally, the renderable should unregister itself as a callback on its subject during release. Note that the renderable only moves back to the uninitialized state during release. This means that the renderable is eligible for re-initialization via a subsequent invocation of draw(GLMapView).

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      void draw​(GLMapView view)
      Renders the content in the current EGL context for the given view.
      void release()
      Releases any resources allocated by the renderable as a result of the invocation of the draw(GLMapView) method.

    • Method Detail

      • draw

        void draw​(GLMapView view)
        Renders the content in the current EGL context for the given view. Initialization of the renderer may occur following instantiation or a prior call to release().

        This method is ALWAYS invoked on the GL thread.

        Parameters:
        view - The current view

      • release

        void release()
        Releases any resources allocated by the renderable as a result of the invocation of the draw(GLMapView) method. This method will be invoked when a renderable that was previously being rendered is no longer eligible for rendering (e.g. a tile that is no longer in view on the map). The renderable may be reinitialized and rendered via a subsequent call to draw(GLMapView) in the future.

        This method is ALWAYS invoked on the GL thread.
